questions.text: As the chief pediatrician in a regional hospital in India, you are called to assess a full-term newborn 16 hours after birth. The initial examination reveals no abnormalities, and you relay this information to the parents. However, the father expresses concern that the baby has not yet passed its first stool or urine. To address his concerns, how would you explain the normal time frame within which a newborn is expected to pass urine and meconium?
questions.correct_answer: A. Urine 24 hrs and Meconium 48 hrs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urine 24 hrs and Meconium 48 hrs.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The normal newborn will pass urine within 24 hrs and Meconium within 48 hrs .
  • • normal newborn will pass urine
  • • 24 hrs and Meconium within 48 hrs
  • • The time taken to reach air to the descending colon is 8-9 hrs .
  • • time taken to reach air to the descending colon is 8-9 hrs
  • • Delayed passage of meconium is seen in case of Hirschsprung's disease for which rectal biopsy is done and most common area affected is rectum
  • • Delayed passage of meconium
  • • Hirschsprung's disease
  • • rectal biopsy is done

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric outpatient department with a 5-month history of rectal bleeding, characterized by fresh blood clearly visible on the stool. The boy reports no significant constipation, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss. His diet is typical for his age, and he is growing appropriately. On examination, his abdomen is soft with mild tenderness on the left side, and stool is palpable in the descending colon. A sentinel skin tag is observed in the perianal area, but no fissures are present. Complete blood count (CBC) is within normal range, and both X-ray and histopathological examination (HPE) of the bowel show no abnormalities. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Meckel’s diverticulum

questions.text: During a routine visit, a mother expresses concern about her 6-month-old child's frequent vomiting, which seems to be non-pathological upon examination. The child appears otherwise healthy with no detectable abnormalities. To address the mother's concerns and provide reassurance, you explain that this is a common occurrence in infants and not indicative of a serious condition. What would you identify as the most common cause of this vomiting in an otherwise healthy infant?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hydrophagia : Hydrophagia refers to excessive drinking of water, which is not typically associated with frequent vomiting in infants unless it leads to water intoxication, which is rare and usually not a common cause of vomiting in this age group.

  • • excessive drinking of water,

  • • Option

  • • excessive milk intake or overfeeding can lead to vomiting in infants
  • • Option D. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition where the esophagus does not develop properly , leading to a gap or blockage . It typically presents with difficulty swallowing, choking, and regurgitation of feedings shortly after birth, rather than at 6 months of age. Additionally, there would likely be abnormalities seen on examination or imaging studies.

questions.text: A mother consults a pediatrician during a routine visit for her 9-month-old baby, expressing concern that the child isn't gaining adequate weight and frequently regurgitates feed hours after eating. The child also has recurrent episodes of coughing associated with the regurgitation. After evaluating the baby, the pediatrician reassures the mother that this is a case of physiological regurgitation, which is common and typically not a cause for concern. The mother then inquires about the age up to which this regurgitation is considered normal without indicating a more serious underlying issue. How should the pediatrician respond?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Till 1 year of life.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clinical Manifestations Infantile reflux manifests more often with regurgitation (especially postprandially), signs of esophagitis (irritability, arching, choking, gagging, feeding aversion), and resulting failure to thrive ; symptoms resolve spontaneously in the majority by 12 months.
  • • Clinical Manifestations
  • • Infantile reflux
  • • regurgitation
  • • signs of esophagitis
  • • failure to thrive
  • • Treatment – reassure the patient till 12 months.
  • • reassure the patient till 12 months.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological regurgitation of feeds is a common occurrence in infants , typically improving as they grow older and develop better control over their feeding and digestive systems . It is considered normal for regurgitation to occur until around 1 year of age in the absence of any concerning symptoms or underlying medical conditions.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is brought to a hospital with symptoms of vomiting and an inability to pass meconium since birth. The physical examination reveals a noticeably distended abdomen and visible peristaltic waves. An X-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, but no air is seen beyond the proximal duodenum, suggesting a lack of passage through the distal duodenum and small intestine. Based on the clinical presentation and X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a gap or blockage in the esophagus . It typically presents shortly after birth with drooling , choking , and difficulty swallowing , but it does not typically present with failure to pass meconium or a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves. Additionally, the X-ray findings described are not consistent with esophageal atresia.
  • • Option A. Esophageal atresia:
  • • congenital condition
  • • gap or blockage in the esophagus
  • • presents shortly after birth with drooling
  • • choking
  • • difficulty swallowing
  • • Option C. Hirschsprung's disease: Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of nerve cells in parts of the large intestine , leading to difficulty passing stool . It typically presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction, such as failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting. However, the X-ray findings described, including a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, are more indicative of a small bowel obstruction rather than Hirschsprung's disease, which primarily affects the large intestine.
  • • Option C. Hirschsprung's disease:
  • • congenital condition characterized by the absence of nerve cells
  • • large intestine
  • • difficulty passing stool
  • • Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a blockage or narrowing in the jejunum , a part of the small intestine . It can present with symptoms similar to duodenal atresia , including vomiting , failure to pass meconium , and abdominal distension . However, the X-ray findings described, specifically the visualization of a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, are more suggestive of a proximal small bowel obstruction, which is consistent with duodenal atresia.
  • • Option
  • • D. Jejunal atresia:
  • • congenital condition
  • • blockage or narrowing in the jejunum
  • • small intestine
  • • duodenal atresia
  • • vomiting
  • • failure to pass meconium
  • • abdominal distension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a blockage or narrowing in the duodenum , the first part of the small intestine . It commonly presents in newborns with vomiting , failure to pass meconium , and a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves . X-ray findings typically show a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels.
  • ➤ Duodenal atresia
  • ➤ congenital
  • ➤ blockage or narrowing in the duodenum
  • ➤ first part of the small intestine
  • ➤ newborns with vomiting
  • ➤ failure to pass meconium
  • ➤ distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old infant with complaints of sudden onset of intermittent, severe abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. The infant draws their legs up to their abdomen and cries loudly when the pain is present. On physical examination, there is a palpable sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. An abdominal x-ray reveals air-fluid levels and an USG revealed a target or bulls eye sign. What is the likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and the radiographical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: It can cause pain and bleeding but is less likely to present with a palpable abdominal mass and the "bull's-eye" sign on ultrasound.
  • • Option A. Meckel's diverticulum:
  • • cause pain and bleeding
  • • Option B. Duodenal atresia: Presents with early-onset vomiting , typically in neonates , and is associated with a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, not the findings described.
  • • Option B. Duodenal atresia:
  • • early-onset vomiting
  • • neonates
  • • Option C. Hirschsprung's disease: Characterized by chronic constipation and abdominal distension due to a lack of enteric nervous system cells in the distal colon ; it does not typically present acutely with a palpable mass and "bull's-eye" sign.
  • • Option C. Hirschsprung's disease:
  • • chronic constipation
  • • abdominal distension
  • • lack of enteric nervous system cells in the distal colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic presentation and ultrasound findings of intussusception in infants , which include sudden, intermittent abdominal pain , bilious vomiting , a palpable sausage-shaped mass , and the "bull's-eye" sign on imaging . Early identification and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as bowel necrosis.

  • ➤ sudden, intermittent abdominal pain

  • ➤ palpable sausage-shaped mass
  • ➤ "bull's-eye" sign on imaging

questions.text: A concerned father rushes his 13-year-old son to the emergency department from school due to 2 days of persistent nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. The boy is in evident distress, experiencing severe pain upon palpation of the abdomen, particularly in the right lower quadrant (RLQ). He describes the pain as initially starting around the periumbilical area before localizing to the RLQ. The boy is tachycardic, febrile, and presents with mild hypertension. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness with notable rebound tenderness in the RLQ, leading to a clinical diagnosis of appendicitis. Among the following statements about appendicitis, which one is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common site of appendix is Retro iliac

options.label: B
options.text: Obturator sign has a significance in appendicitis.

options.label: C
options.text: Contrast Enhanced CT is the initial investigation in children

options.label: D
options.text: Psoas sign has no significance in appendicitis.

questions.correct_answer: B. Obturator sign has a significance in appendicitis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obturator sign has a significance in appendicitis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Retroiliac: The most common location of the appendix is not retroiliac but rather in the RLQ of the abdomen, specifically at the McBurney's point.
  • • Option
  • • A. Retroiliac:
  • • most common location
  • • appendix
  • • Option C. Contrast-Enhanced CT: In children , ultrasound is often the initial imaging modality of choice for suspected appendicitis to avoid radiation exposure . CT may be used subsequently if ultrasound findings are inconclusive and the clinical suspicion remains high.
  • • Option
  • • C. Contrast-Enhanced CT:
  • • children
  • • ultrasound
  • • initial imaging modality
  • • suspected appendicitis
  • • avoid radiation exposure
  • • Option D. Psoas Sign: The psoas sign is actually significant in appendicitis , especially when the inflamed appendix is positioned against the iliopsoas muscle . The sign is elicited by extending the hip, with the patient lying on their left side, which can cause pain in cases of appendicitis.
  • • Option
  • • D. Psoas Sign:
  • • appendicitis
  • • inflamed appendix is positioned against the iliopsoas muscle

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During pediatric rounds, you're reviewing a case involving hyperbilirubinemia. The attending consultant quizzes the team, asking, "In pediatric patients, what is the foremost reason for undergoing liver transplantation?" How should you respond?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Biliary atresia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Weil’s disease: This condition, caused by Leptospira bacteria , can lead to severe liver damage but is not the leading cause of liver transplantation in children.
  • • Option
  • • A. Weil’s disease:
  • • Leptospira bacteria
  • • lead to severe liver damage
  • • Option B. Fulminant hepatic failure: While this acute liver failure could necessitate urgent liver transplantation , it is not as common as biliary atresia in pediatric patients requiring this intervention.
  • • Option
  • • B. Fulminant hepatic failure:
  • • acute liver failure
  • • urgent liver transplantation
  • • Option D. Wilson's disease: A genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in organs , including the liver . Although it can lead to liver failure, biliary atresia is more frequently the cause of liver transplantation in the pediatric population.
  • • Option
  • • D. Wilson's disease:
  • • genetic disorder
  • • copper accumulation in organs
  • • liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biliary atresia is the most prevalent indication for liver transplantation in the pediatric demographic , underscoring the significance of early detection and intervention to avert the progression to irreversible liver damage.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric department due to experiencing five episodes of loose stools. questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 10 mg for 10-14 days.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For infants and children with acute diarrhea , the WHO recommends zinc supplementation as part of the management . The recommended dosage for infants under 6 months of age is 10 mg of zinc per day for 10-14 days . Zinc supplementation during diarrhea episodes has been shown to reduce the duration and severity of the episode and may also have a prophylactic effect against future episodes for 2-3 months.

questions.text: A mother presents her 6-year-old son to the clinic, reporting dysphagia. Upon examination, the child shows no signs of respiratory distress. A chest X-ray reveals radiopaque findings suggestive of a foreign body aspiration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wait and Watch

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Immediate Tracheoscopic removal: Tracheoscopic removal is indicated if there are signs of severe airway obstruction or respiratory distress . However, in stable patients without such signs, immediate intervention may not be necessary.
  • • Option
  • • A. Immediate Tracheoscopic removal:
  • • there are signs of severe airway obstruction
  • • respiratory distress
  • • Option B. Immediate Esophagoscopic removal: Esophagoscopic removal is appropriate if the foreign body is confirmed to be lodged in the esophagus and causing symptoms. However, if the location is uncertain or if the patient is asymptomatic, immediate intervention may not be warranted.
  • • Option
  • • B. Immediate Esophagoscopic removal:
  • • foreign body is confirmed to be lodged in the esophagus
  • • Option D. Immediate Laryngoscopic removal: Laryngoscopic removal is indicated if the foreign body is visible in the larynx or upper airway and causing significant obstruction. However, if there are no signs of upper airway compromise, immediate intervention may not be required.
  • • Option
  • • D. Immediate Laryngoscopic removal:
  • • foreign body is visible in the larynx or upper airway

options.text: ORS with low-lactose diet and probiotics

questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. ORS with antibiotics: Antibiotics are not routinely recommended for acute watery diarrhea unless there is evidence of bacterial infection or specific indications for antibiotic therapy.
  • • Option
  • • A. ORS with antibiotics:
  • • not routinely recommended for acute watery diarrhea
  • • Option C. ORS with low-lactose diet: While a low-lactose diet may be beneficial in cases of lactose intolerance , it is not the primary intervention for managing acute diarrhea, especially in the initial stages of treatment.
  • • Option
  • • C. ORS with low-lactose diet:
  • • low-lactose diet may be beneficial in cases of lactose intolerance
  • • Option D. ORS with low-lactose diet and probiotics: While these interventions may have potential benefits , they are not the initial management priority in acute diarrhea, which requires prompt rehydration with ORS.
  • • Option
  • • D. ORS with low-lactose diet and probiotics:
  • • interventions may have potential benefits

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In managing acute diarrhea in infants , oral rehydration solution (ORS) plays a central role in restoring hydration and electrolyte balance , which are essential for recovery. ORS contains the optimal balance of electrolytes and glucose to replace fluid losses due to diarrhea and prevent dehydration . It is the cornerstone of treatment recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for managing acute diarrhea in children.
  • ➤ acute diarrhea in infants
  • ➤ oral rehydration solution
  • ➤ central role in restoring hydration and electrolyte balance
  • ➤ ORS
  • ➤ optimal balance of electrolytes
  • ➤ glucose to replace fluid losses
  • ➤ diarrhea and prevent dehydration
  • ➤ While zinc supplementation , low-lactose diet , and probiotics can be beneficial in certain cases, the initial management priority is to ensure adequate rehydration with ORS . Antibiotics are not routinely indicated in cases of acute watery diarrhea unless there is evidence of bacterial etiology or severe illness requiring targeted treatment. A low-lactose diet and probiotics may be considered in cases of lactose intolerance or persistent diarrhea, but they do not replace the primary role of ORS in managing acute diarrhea.
